Dear Mr. Hawkins:
Attached is the Special Investigation Report for the above referenced facility. Due to the
violations identified in the report, a written corrective action plan is required. The
corrective action plan is due 15 days from the date of this letter and must include the
following:
 How compliance with each rule will be achieved.
 Who is directly responsible for implementing the corrective action for each
violation.
 Specific time frames for each violation as to when the correction will be
completed or implemented.
 How continuing compliance will be maintained once compliance is
achieved.
 The signature of the responsible party and a date.
If you desire technical assistance in addressing these issues, please feel free to contact
me. In any event, the corrective action plan is due within 15 days. Failure to submit an
acceptable corrective action plan will result in disciplinary action.
Please note that violations of any licensing rules are also violations of the MSISEP and
your contract.
Please review the enclosed documentation for accuracy and contact me with any
questions. In the event that I am not available, and you need to speak to someone
immediately, please contact the local office at (616)552-3662.

ALLEGATION:
On 1/05/21, youth ran at another youth at the facility and a staff member stepped in
between to block them from assaulting each other. Staff was facing one youth and
unaware of the youth behind them. When staff moved, youth’s arm hit the wall. Youth
had arm pain the following day
INVESTIGATION:
On 1/7/2021 I received an email from Administrator 1 indicating that the facility’s
medical team checked Youth B and he did not report any pain or injury.
611 W. OTTAWA  P.O. BOX 30664  LANSING, MICHIGAN 48909
www.michigan.gov/lara  517-335-1980

Administrator 1 also reported that, per the established safety plan, Supervisor 1 has
been suspended pending investigation.
Video Footage-
On 1/7/2021 I received and reviewed video footage of the 1/5/2021 incident. Youth A
runs down a hallway toward Youth B. Supervisor 1 is standing between the two and
moves his body against a wall, which prevents Youth A from reaching Youth B.
Youth B walked up close behind Supervisor 1 at the time Supervisor 1 moves toward
the wall and Youth B’s arm gets pinned between the wall and Supervisor 1’s body
for a few seconds. Afterward, Youth A can be heard screaming that Supervisor 1
intentionally hurt his arm. A second video clip was reviewed during which Supervisor
1, Staff 3, and Youth B are in the hallway discussing the incident. While it is difficult
to discern all of what is being said, Supervisor 1 can be heard laughing in response
to Youth B, and becoming verbally escalated along with Youth B. During this
interaction, Youth B escalated to the point of an asthma attack. After Youth B is
administered his inhaler by Staff 3, he is heard crying followed by Supervisor 1
asking Youth B, “are you going to cry about it, or do you want to go to your room”
after which Youth B continues to escalate and Supervisor 1 follows him out of
camera view and yells the question “do you want to go to your room” repeatedly.
On 1/7/2021 I made an unannounced visit to the facility along with DHHS Worker 1
at which time we interviewed Youth B who reported that he “just got in the way”
when Supervisor moved to block Youth A who was running toward him. Youth B
stated that his arm was pinned by accident and that he did not have any pain or
injury from the incident. He reported no concerns with any of the staff in the home.
On 1/14/2021 I interviewed Supervisor 1 in person, along with DHHS Worker 1.
Supervisor 1 reported that, on 1/4/2021 he was coming off of a 14-hour shift and had
been working a lot of hours in general. He reported that he and Staff 2 were called to
provide back-up to Staff 3 & 4 because Youth A & B were fighting. Supervisor 1 and
Staff 2 were across campus from the home in which Youth A & B are placed, so he
ran to the home. He stated that he can’t recall the specifics related to the allegation
made by Youth B, but he does recall Youth A saying that he might have hurt his arm.
He did recall “body blocking” Youth A from getting to Youth B, which he stated is
trained to staff during CPI training as a method of keeping a youth from a “target.”
He reported that body blocking can be used as long as staff don’t restrict youth’s
arms.
Supervisor 1 reported that he was escalated throughout is interaction with Youth B
and regrets his behavior/choices on that day. He recognized that the way he spoke
with Youth B further escalated the youth. Supervisor 1 stated that he was frustrated
during the incident and that, when he is frustrated, he is not effective.
On 2/1/2021, Administrator 1 called me to report that she spoke with the CPI trainer
regarding Supervisor 1’s report that “body blocking” is taught to staff. Administrator 1
stated that the CPI trainer did state that he uses the term body block when teaching
611 W. OTTAWA  P.O. BOX 30664  LANSING, MICHIGAN 48909
www.michigan.gov/lara  517-335-1980

staff to use body placement to keep a youth safe. Administrator 1 stated that the
trainer will no longer use this terminology as it is not a CPI approved intervention
and staff members seem to have adopted the language. Administrator 1 also
reported that Supervisor 1 has been demoted to a direct care staff position and is
under a performance improvement plan.
APPLICABLE RULE
R 400.4157 Behavior management.
(1) An institution shall establish and follow written policies
and procedures that describe the institution’s behavior
management system. The policies and procedures shall
be reviewed annually and updated as needed. These
shall be available to all residents, their families, and
referring agencies.
ANALYSIS: Supervisor 1 did not violate the behavior management system
when he moved his body to block Youth A from Youth B.
Technical Assistance was provided regarding the use of body
blocking by staff members. The concern is related to Supervisor
1 reporting that this is a CPI method; however, a body block
does not involve any type of CPI hold.
CONCLUSION: VIOLATION NOT ESTABLISHED
ADDITIONAL FINDINGS:
INVESTIGATION:
As noted in the above investigation, Staff 1 was heard verbally escalating Youth B
during their interaction and admitted that he was frustrated and inappropriate in what
he said to the youth.
APPLICABLE RULE
R 400.4158 Discipline.
(2) An institution shall prohibit all cruel and severe
discipline, including any of the following:
(c) Verbal abuse, ridicule, or humiliation.

CONCLUSION: REPEAT VIOLATION ESTABLISHED

ADDITIONAL FINDINGS:
During review of video footage from 1/5/2021, Supervisor 1 was observed not
wearing a face mask.
INVESTIGATION:
Video Footage-
On 1/7/2021 I received and reviewed video footage of Supervisor and Youth B
talking with one another. During this interaction, Supervisor 1 sounds escalated and
rips off his face mask, appearing to break the straps, then tosses it on the ground
next to him. His mask remains off throughout the interaction other than brief
moments where he holds it over his nose and mouth.
On 2/3/2020 I reviewed the facility’s Emergency Management Response Plan
COVID-19 Critical Response Plan.
APPLICABLE RULE
R 400.4151 Emergency; continuity of operation procedures.
(1) An institution shall establish and follow written
emergency procedures
that have been approved by the department that maintain
the continuity of operations for a minimum of 72 hours to
assure the safety of residents for the following
circumstances:
(a) Fire.
(b) Severe weather.
(c) Medical emergencies.
(d) Missing persons.
(f) Disasters.
(g) Utility failures.
